title: Inserting a tensor into a python dict causes strange behavior
body_html:
Reported from https://discuss.pytorch.org/t/why-tensor-is-hashable/18225

T = torch.randn(5,5)
c = hash(T)  # i.e. c = 140676925984200
dic = dict()
dic[T] = 100
dic[c] 
RuntimeError: bool value of Tensor with more than one value is ambiguous.

I'm not sure if we support using Tensors as keys in python dicts; but Tensor does have a hash method.
body_text:
Reported from https://discuss.pytorch.org/t/why-tensor-is-hashable/18225
T = torch.randn(5,5)
c = hash(T)  # i.e. c = 140676925984200
dic = dict()
dic[T] = 100
dic[c] 
RuntimeError: bool value of Tensor with more than one value is ambiguous.

I'm not sure if we support using Tensors as keys in python dicts; but Tensor does have a hash method.
body:
Reported from https://discuss.pytorch.org/t/why-tensor-is-hashable/18225 
```
T = torch.randn(5,5)
c = hash(T)  # i.e. c = 140676925984200
dic = dict()
dic[T] = 100
dic[c] 
RuntimeError: bool value of Tensor with more than one value is ambiguous.
```

I'm not sure if we support using Tensors as keys in python dicts; but Tensor does have a __hash__ method.
